Title.evidence: Long-term Impact of Mesh Type on Chronic Pain in Open Anterior Inguinal Hernia Repair: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size calculation required 240 patients to detect a reduction in pain from 30% to 15% with 80% power.

Participants.evidence: men aged 25 years or older with symptomatic unilateral inguinal hernia

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised (1:1) to receive either heavyweight (90 g/m²) or lightweight (28 g/m²) mesh.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the long-term effects of heavyweight versus lightweight mesh on chronic pain following open anterior inguinal hernia repair.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was chronic pain affecting daily activities, measured by the Short-Form Inguinal Pain Questionnaire 9–12 years post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed via a web-based server.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 412 randomised patients, 363 were analysed, with 271 completing the follow-up (121 heavyweight, 150 lightweight).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 412 randomised patients, 363 were analysed, with 271 completing the follow-up (121 heavyweight, 150 lightweight).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Pain affecting daily activities was significantly less in the lightweight group (generalized odds 1.33, 95% CI 1.10 to 1.61; p = 0.004), translating to a number needed to treat of 7.06 (95% CI 4.28 to 21.44).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by Umeå University.
